content.definition: Hybrid surgical technique that creates extra-anatomic bypasses to the aortic arch branches, allowing subsequent endovascular exclusion of arch pathology with TEVAR. Avoids the need for deep hypothermic circulatory arrest while extending TEVAR landing zones proximally.

indication: Arch aneurysm in high-risk open surgical candidate
Extension of descending thoracic aneurysm into arch
Arch involvement in Type B dissection
Need for proximal landing zone in zone 0-2

technique.chimney_technique: Parallel stents to maintain branch vessel flow

staged_vs_simultaneous: Staged: Debranching first, TEVAR 2-4 weeks later

outcomes.mortality: 5-15% (lower than open arch surgery in high-risk)
outcomes.spinal_cord_ischemia: Risk increases with extensive aortic coverage

clinical_pearls: Debranching extends TEVAR landing zone proximally
Zone 2 landing (left subclavian) often requires carotid-subclavian bypass
Left subclavian coverage without revascularization acceptable in selected patients
Retrograde Type A dissection is devastating complication of proximal TEVAR
Branched/fenestrated endografts may eventually replace debranching

learning_objectives: Describe indications for arch debranching vs open repair
Outline debranching options by landing zone requirement
Recognize complications specific to hybrid arch repair
